Award.AwardTitle: RUI:Directed Molecular Architectural Assembly via Dynamic Covalent Chemistry
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program at the National Science Foundation supports the work of Professor Darren Hamilton at Mount Holyoke College concerning the development and utilization of a new approach for the thermodynamically controlled assembly of molecular architectures. This research builds upon the viability of classic conjugate addition chemistry to establish, under reversible conditions, carbon frameworks of elaborate overall structure. In particular, the formation of topologically complex organic molecules-rotaxanes and catenanes-is facilitated via this approach, opening a straightforward route to materials with potentially valuable imaging and sensing properties.

With support from this award students at Mount Holyoke, an undergraduate only women's college, work on projects that span organic synthesis, structural analysis, and investigations of the properties of new materials. A premium is placed on establishing concise, inexpensive, modular methods of broad general applicability to the preparation of materials for contemporary problems such as sensing and imaging. Contributions to US competitiveness in these fields is derived from both the specific research undertaken with support from this award, and from the preparation of new generations of undergraduates trained in emerging areas of synthetic and materials chemistry. Collaborations with local high school teachers are supported with the intention of drawing illustrative components of the research into laboratory teaching.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the course of this award the Principal Investigator collaborated with undergraduate students in both research and teaching settings to develop a program of chemical synthesis and investigation with a primary specific goal: to fully explore the parameters and potential of an approach to material synthesis that had emerged from earlier work in the Principal Investigator’s laboratory. This work had two distinct themes, and two venues for prosecution and application. The two distinct themes for the work, which were pursued and developed in parallel, were the design and optimization of key building blocks, and their related chemistry, and the application of this knowledge, as it was developed and refined, to the preparation of structurally elaborate materials. The two venues in which this work was developed were the research laboratory and an advanced teaching laboratory experience, the latter of which served as an excellent introduction to more advanced research endeavors for undergraduates.

A family of certain chemical reactions, of which the reaction at the center of this work is a member, exhibit the useful property of being reversible. Under appropriate conditions these reactions both form and break chemical bonds, thereby realizing a form of molecular level proof-reading. In effect molecular structures are subject to editing, with the most stable structure predominating at equilibrium. With careful design a desirable molecular structure can serve as this point of maximum stability, providing a target for the editing process. This general approach to the self-assembly of complex molecular architectures has proven both powerful and versatile over the past decade. Our approach introduced a new reaction to this field, one in which carbon-carbon bond formation is key. In the field of organic chemistry the construction of carbon frameworks is of paramount importance and the rare addition of a new reaction of reversible character that allows for this process is therefore of significance. An additional attribute of our approach is that only mild changes in reaction conditions are typically needed to induce the reversible reaction and, equally importantly, to stop this process.

The self-assembly processes that may be designed around the use of a reversible reaction may include some whose macroscopic analogy might be the seemingly impossible insertion of a fully rigged model ship into a narrow necked glass bottle. Prominent examples of molecular structures that lie within this general category include molecules where a dumbbell shaped component is located within the cavity of a ring shaped molecule, or where two ring molecules are mutually interlocked; for each, the “impossible” topology is accomplished via the reversible assembly/disassembly process. Examples in both of these general categories have been prepared in this work, both to serve as models for the general chemistry we have developed and to allow us to explore the structural possibilities to which our approach might provide access. Drawing inspiration from recent research that has demonstrated improved imaging and therapeutic properties from certain classes of dyes when encapsulated, this is included in the kind of complex molecular context to which our approach can provide ready access, we have most recently attempted to adapt our approach to encompass use of these materials.

As befits an award made to an undergraduate institution, efforts have been made throughout to provide opportunity and access to the research program for students of various backgrounds and degrees of preparation. While a reasonable level of laboratory experience is required in order to approach new experimentation with confidence, contributions to the fine tuning and optimization of reaction conditions may be made at the more inexperienced level.
